The result, stated in a concise form, is: To find the value of the I.V. which makes the function a maximum or minimum, differentiating the function, equate to zero and solve.
The full merit of the method can be best appreciated by the discussion of a somewhat standard problem before proceeding to a more practical nature.
To find the values of the I.V. which give the extremes for the function x = x² − 3x + 2, subject to a minimum value.
Thus, we can see that from the graphical aspect.
Let the first of the primitive curve y = x³ − 3x² − 36x + 5 (See Fig. 25), the table of values for which is shown.

blocks.caption: Figure 25: Graph of the primitive curve showing the values of the derivative.
blocks.description: The graph demonstrates the behavior of the function and its derivative. The curve has points where the slope changes, indicating potential maximum and minimum points.

blocks.text: By two turning points, we see that when the primitive curve has a turning value, the value of dy/dx = 0.
Thus, for values of x between −3 and −2 the slope of the primitive is negative; when x = −2 the slope is zero, and from x = −2 to +2 the slope is positive.
